feed.title: Blogger Developers Network
feed.subtitle: The official Blogger Developers Network weblog.

entry.title: Blogger API v3
entry.summary:
One of the most requested features that developers have for the Blogger JSON API is the ability to create posts. So have a quick guess what the following HTTP request does?
POST https://www.googleapis.com/blogger/v3/blogs/8070105920543249955/posts/ HTTP/1.0 Host: www.googleapis.com Authorization: Bearer <OAuth2 key> Content-Type: application/json
{ "kind": "blogger#post", "blog": { "id

entry.title: Blogger Documentation has moved to developers.google.com
entry.summary:
Blogger documentation has a new home: it has moved to developers.google.com/blogger!
I have re-arranged the documentation a little to make it easier to navigate, but it is largely the same documentation you will remember from code.google.com/apis/blogger. If you find anything is out of place or hard to find, please let us know on the Blogger Developer forum.

link.title: Blogger Documentation has moved to developers.google.com

entry.title: Customising Threaded Comments
entry.summary:
Recently we released an update to Blogger’s commenting system that enables people to directly respond to comments. This capability is known as Threaded Comments. We are pleased to see quite a few people diving in and writing tutorials, including a screencast. It’s wonderful to see the enthusiasm of our developers!
In this post we will look at what are the changes required to modify a custom

entry.title: An easier to use interface for the Blogger JSON API
entry.summary: As I have been reviewing the applications to use the Blogger JSON API, I have noticed that a fair number of you appear to be integrating with Blogger JSON API using JavaScript. So, in the interests of making things easier for all of you, here is a walk through of using the just released JavaScript Client Library for Google APIs to access the Blogger JSON API. link.title: An easier to use interface for the Blogger JSON API

entry.title: Changes to ProfileID for Google+ profile users
entry.summary:
It’s wonderful to see a lot of our users taking us up on our offer to merge our Blogger Profile with the Google+ Profile. For developers this means that there is one small wrinkle to worry about - the format of the ProfileId for these migrated users has changed.
What’s a ProfileId, and what’s it used for?
The ProfileId is a component of the path for the Retrieving a List of Blogs Blogger GData

link.title: Changes to ProfileID for Google+ profile users
